articles.headline: Winner Uses Contest Site and Loses Grand Prize
articles.snippet: A winner of an online contest was disqualified for using a Web site where people who enter digital sweepstakes ask members to vote for them.
articles.abstract: A winner of an online contest was disqualified for using a Web site where people who enter digital sweepstakes ask members to vote for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: After working as a lawyer for 22 years, Theodore A. Scott wanted a break. So he entered a contest sponsored by Gold Peak Tea, a Coca-Cola tea brand, offering the ultimate respite for weary workers: a year off work and a $100,000 prize.

articles.headline: Payroll Tax Cut Is Unlikely to Survive Into Next Year
articles.snippet: A tax break for 160 million wage earners, pushed last winter by the White House, now finds little support in Washington, as Congress struggles with deficits and turns its attention to the Bush-era income tax cuts.
articles.abstract: A tax break for 160 million wage earners, pushed last winter by the White House, now finds little support in Washington, as Congress struggles with deficits and turns its attention to the Bush-era income tax cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Regardless of who wins the presidential election in November or what compromises Congress strikes in the lame-duck session to keep the economy from automatic tax increases and spending cuts, 160 million American wage earners will probably see their tax bills jump after Jan. 1.

articles.headline: U.S. May Have Put Mistaken Faith in Libya Site’s Security
articles.snippet: Defenses at the American mission in Benghazi have become a major issue as the Obama administration struggles to explain what happened there and how Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens ended up alone.
articles.abstract: Defenses at the American mission in Benghazi have become a major issue as the Obama administration struggles to explain what happened there and how Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens ended up alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An effective response by newly trained Libyan security guards to a small bombing outside the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi in June may have led United States officials to underestimate the security threat to personnel there, according to counterterrorism and State Department officials, even as threat warnings grew in the weeks before the recent attack that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, David D. Kirkpatrick and Suliman Ali Zway

articles.headline: Proudly Bearing Elders’ Scars, Their Skin Says ‘Never Forget’
articles.snippet: Some descendants of Holocaust survivors are having their concentration-camp numbers tattooed on their arms, a practice that provokes mixed reactions and a lot of conversation.
articles.abstract: Some descendants of Holocaust survivors are having their concentration-camp numbers tattooed on their arms, a practice that provokes mixed reactions and a lot of conversation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Eli Sagir showed her grandfather, Yosef Diamant, the new tattoo on her left forearm, he bent his head to kiss it.

articles.headline: ‘North Dakota Nice’ Plays Well in Senate Race
articles.snippet: Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat running for the Senate, is well liked in this conservative state, making the contest a real fight.
articles.abstract: Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat running for the Senate, is well liked in this conservative state, making the contest a real fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINOT, N.D. — Heidi Heitkamp, a Democratic Senate candidate, called Leonard Rademacher a few weeks ago looking for his vote, but Mr. Rademacher, a 74-year-old retiree, was feeling ill, so Ms. Heitkamp called him back.
